context:
<Summary source="https://tradingeconomics.com/pakistan/interest-rate">
Summary of Article on Pakistan Interest Rate:

Key Facts and Statistics:
1. Current Policy Rate: 10.5% (as of January 2026)
2. Inflation: 
   - December rate: 5.6% (three-month low)
   - Within target range of 5-7%
3. GDP Growth:
   - Q1-FY26: 3.7% year-on-year (up from 1.6% in previous year)
   - Projected FY26 GDP growth: 3.75–4.75%
4. Historical Interest Rate Context:
   - Average from 1992-2026: 11.63%
   - All-time high: 22% (June 2023)
   - All-time low: 5.75% (May 2016)

Projections and Expectations:
1. Short-term expectation: Interest rate expected to be 10% by end of current quarter
2. Long-term projection: Interest rate may trend around 7% in 2027

Contextual Insights:
- SBP kept policy rate unchanged at 10.5% in January, surprising markets
- Central bank projects inflation to remain within target range through FY26 and FY27
- Current rate seen as supporting price stability and economic growth
- External economic factors include widening current account deficit, but steady remittances and ICT exports

Source Reliability: Official State Bank of Pakistan statements and Trading Economics global macro models
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://tribune.com.pk/story/2589142/state-bank-holds-monetary-policy-rate-at-105">
Summary of the Article:

Key Facts and Statistics:
1. Current Policy Rate: 10.5% (maintained as of January 26, 2026)
2. Inflation Outlook: 5-7% going into 2027
3. Economic Growth Projection: 3.75-4.75% in current fiscal year
4. Current Account Deficit: $1.2 billion in first half of fiscal year
5. Foreign Exchange Reserves: $16.1 billion (expected to exceed $18 billion by June)

Official Stance:
- State Bank of Pakistan's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decided to keep the policy rate unchanged
- Rationale: Support price stability and sustainable economic growth
- Headline inflation eased to 5.6% in December from 6.1% in November

Market and Industry Reaction:
- Strong market expectations for rate cut (pre-policy survey):
  - 43.5% expected 75 basis points cut
  - 39.1% anticipated 50 basis points reduction
  - Only 17.4% expected no change

Industry Criticism:
- Business community views the decision as:
  - Counterproductive
  - Disconnected from economic realities
- FPCCI President Atif Ikram Sheikh demanded:
  - 350 basis points cut to bring rate to 7%
  - Immediate review of monetary stance
  - Declaration of "industrial emergency"

Risks and Caveats Noted by MPC:
- Potential volatility in:
  - Global commodity prices
  - Domestic wheat prices
  - Administrative energy prices
  - Domestic demand fluctuations
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://english.news.cn/20260126/28c5b6ceb2f54487b33bff957d89be97/c.html">
Summary of Article:

Key Facts and Statistics:
1. State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) kept policy rate unchanged at 10.5%
2. Headline inflation eased to 5.6% year-on-year in December 2025
3. Core inflation remained around 7.4%
4. Real GDP growth: 3.7% in first quarter of fiscal year 2026 (vs 1.6% in same period last year)
5. Current account deficit: $244 million in December 2025, cumulative $1.2 billion in first half of fiscal year
6. Foreign exchange reserves: $16.1 billion as of January 16, 2026
7. Broad money growth: 16.3% in early January

Monetary Policy Committee Observations:
- Economic activity gaining momentum, driven by domestic-oriented sectors
- Trade deficit widened due to increased imports and declining exports
- Workers' remittances and benign global commodity prices helped contain current account deficit
- Tax revenue growth slowed, falling short of targets
- Higher private sector credit and government borrowing driving money supply growth

Notably, the article represents a snapshot of the monetary policy situation in January 2026, which provides context for potential policy rate considerations, though it does not explicitly predict the May 1, 2026 rate.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://tribune.com.pk/story/2589142/state-bank-holds-monetary-policy-rate-at-105">
Summary of Article:

Key Facts and Statistics:
1. Current Policy Rate: 10.5% (as of January 26, 2026)
2. Inflation Outlook: 5-7% going into 2027
3. Economic Growth Projection: 3.75-4.75% in current fiscal year
4. Current Account Deficit: $244 million in December 2025, $1.2 billion in first half of fiscal year
5. Foreign Exchange Reserves: $16.1 billion (expected to exceed $18 billion by June)

Official Stance:
- State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) Governor Jameel Ahmad announced maintaining the monetary policy at 10.5%
- Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decided to hold policy rate unchanged
- Rationale: Support economic stability, ensure price stability, and support sustainable economic growth

Market and Industry Reaction:
- Strong disappointment from business community
- Pre-policy survey showed expectations of rate cuts:
  - 43.5% expected 75 basis points cut
  - 39.1% anticipated 50 basis points reduction
  - 17.4% expected no change

Industry Critiques:
- FPCCI President Atif Ikram Sheikh: Demanded 350 basis points cut to 7%
- Argued high borrowing costs are causing industrial closures
- Criticized SBP's cautious approach as disconnected from economic realities

Contextual Notes:
- Headline inflation eased to 5.6% in December from 6.1% in November
- Real GDP growth provisionally reported at 3.7% in first quarter
- Consumer and business confidence improving
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.dawn.com/news/1960682">
Summary of the Article:

Key Facts and Statistics:
1. Current Policy Rate: 11% (held steady since September)
2. Inflation Rate: 
   - November: 6.1% (down from 6.2% in October)
   - SBP's target range: 5-7%
   - IMF expects temporary acceleration to 8-10% this fiscal year

Reliable Source Opinions:
1. IMF Recommendations:
   - Monetary policy should remain "appropriately tight and data-dependent"
   - Maintain positive real interest rates
   - Caution against premature easing

2. Analyst Expectations:
   - All 12 analysts surveyed expect no rate cut in the upcoming meeting
   - Most predict first rate cut in closing months of FY 2026 (some even push to FY 2027)
   - Reasons: persistent inflation risks, external pressures

3. Specific Expert Quote:
   - Sana Tawfik (Arif Habib Ltd): Demand-driven uptick could "have an adverse impact on the external front"

Context:
- Previous rate cuts: 1,100 basis points between June 2024 and May 2025
- Inflation previously near 40% in 2023
- Upcoming IMF disbursement of $1.2 billion for reserves and climate-resilience reforms

The article suggests a cautious approach to monetary policy, with no immediate rate cuts expected.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://wincountry.com/2025/10/27/pakistan-central-bank-holds-interest-rate-at-11-for-fourth-time-in-a-row/">
Summary of the Article:

Key Facts and Statistics:
1. State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) kept its key interest rate unchanged at 11% for the fourth consecutive time
2. GDP forecast for fiscal year 2026 revised to upper half of 3.25–4.25% range
3. Inflation expected to:
   - Stay above 5–7% target range for a few months in second half of current fiscal year
   - Ease within target range in next fiscal year
4. Current account deficit expected to remain within 0–1% of GDP in fiscal 2026
5. Foreign exchange reserves projected to:
   - Reach $15.5 billion by December 2025
   - Reach around $17.8 billion by June 2026

Reliable Source Opinions:
- All 10 analysts surveyed expected the central bank to hold policy rate steady
- SBP aims to maintain price stability as previous rate cuts continue to work through the economy

Contextual Notes:
- SBP has lowered rates by 1,100 basis points since June 2024 (when rates peaked at 22%)
- Most recent rate cut was in May
- Macroeconomic outlook has improved since last meeting

Potential Risk Factors Mentioned:
- Volatile global commodity prices
- Future energy price adjustments
- Uncertainty around wheat and perishable food prices
</Summary>
